headline.main: Film View; PLAIN FOLKS ARE PLAIN TOUGH

docs.lead_paragraph: We are under siege by ordinary people. Those aren't ''Dawn of the Dead'' ghouls stalking our movie screens in ever-increasing numbers but comparatively common folk who are coping, in one way and another, with a lot of the problems the rest of us face. The uncommon truth about these films is not that there are so many, but that so many of them manage to be as good as they are - making respectable films about ordinary people isn't easy. The two newest on the scene: Alan Alda's often funny, completely uncritical ''The Four Seasons,'' about three married couples who are seen entirely in terms of the vacations they take together, and Jan Egleson's ''The Dark at the End of the Street,'' a very good, beautifully acted, independently made film about blue-collar life in and around Boston.
